existing_custody_order.reasoning: Paragraph 3.1 expressly alleges an Existing Order entered April 15, 2021 establishing Plaintiff’s primary physical custody and Defendant’s every-other-weekend and one-weeknight overnight parenting time; the complaint therefore pleads an existing custody/parenting-time order.

specific_modification_sought.reasoning: Section 6.1 (and subparts i–ii, C–F) sets out concrete modifications sought: restrict overnights to nights Defendant is off-duty (or require verifiable advance proof), convert overnights to daytime/evening when he works, require advance notice and vetting of third parties, provide work schedule to the parties/the Court, and related temporary relief—a specific and measurable change to the Existing Order.

material_substantial_change.reasoning: Section 4.1–4.5 allege factual changes since the Existing Order: Defendant accepted night-shift work (7pm–7am) that overlaps scheduled overnights, is frequently fatigued/unable to supervise, has left the children with a roommate or returned them with little notice, and children report Defendant sleeps and is inattentive—allegations that plausibly describe a material and substantial change affecting the children’s care and routine.

best_interests_of_child.reasoning: The complaint links the alleged change in circumstances to risks to the children’s health, safety, welfare and stability (¶¶4.5, 4.6, 6.1(A)–(B)) and expressly asks for modifications to protect the children pending hearing (¶¶7.1, 8.2). Those factual allegations reasonably plead that the requested modification is necessary for the children’s best interests.
